exercise: Create an empty set called 'numbers'. Use the add() method to add the integers 1, 2, and 3 to the set. Print the set after each addition.
Create a set with the string 'Hello'. Use the add() method to add the string 'World' to the set. Print the final set.
Create an empty set. Add the boolean values True and False to it using the add() method. Print the set.
Create a set with the integer 10. Try to add the same integer 10 again using the add() method. Print the set and explain what happened.
Create an empty set called 'fruits'. Add 'apple', 'banana', and 'cherry' to the set using the add() method. Then try to add 'apple' again. Print the final set and its length.
Create a set with the value 5. Add a floating-point number (5.0) to this set using the add() method. Print the set and explain whether 5.0 was added as a separate element and why.
Create an empty set. Use the add() method to add a tuple (1, 2) to the set. Print the set. Then try to add a list [3, 4] to the set. What happens and why?
Write a function that takes a list as input and returns a set containing only unique elements from the list, using the add() method rather than direct set conversion.
Create a set of even numbers from 2 to 10. Write a loop that attempts to add each number from 1 to 15 to this set. Print the final set and explain which numbers were actually added.
Write a function that takes a string as input and uses the add() method to build a set of all unique characters in the string. Compare your function's result with simply using set(input_string).
